item.title: Encryption algorithm strength
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“sp11k3t3ht3rd, post:26, topic:431315”][quote author=t4 link=topic=533991.msg3904179#msg3904179 date=1328056716]

Could be unhashed with an linear attack I do believe. You are practically just doing a modulus operation with no other transformation operations? I think the part that would take some thought would be figuring out how many characters there are in the hashed text.

-Amount of represented characters in the string must equal the amount of represented characters in the key.

Is that a rule that you have to follow?

would you like to provide the decryption algorithm please

I don’t know how to decrypt it. Well The mod part is the part that kills me. I don’t know how I could get back to the original bytes used. But I guess that’s a win considering I just wanted to prevent brute forcing the password, unless my understanding of this is completely wrong.

if data is not able to be recovered then that’s a hashing algorithm. at that point just use SHA1 or even MD5 because chances are your algorithm has many collisions.

Then should I just perform other operations instead of the modulus?

modulus is great, it’s just in its purest form you lose information:

m mod n:
5 mod 3 = 2
8 mod 3 = 2

How do you know if 2 came from 5, 8, …, m without retaining how many modulus steps were taken?
[/quote]

I know how modulus works, but then doesn’t its use then basically make it a hash function because its “almost” impossible to the back to the original number. Well not almost impossible, but take a lot of time.

Could be unhashed with an linear attack I do believe. You are practically just doing a modulus operation with no other transformation operations? I think the part that would take some thought would be figuring out how many characters there are in the hashed text.

-Amount of represented characters in the string must equal the amount of represented characters in the key.

Is that a rule that you have to follow?

would you like to provide the decryption algorithm please

I don’t know how to decrypt it. Well The mod part is the part that kills me. I don’t know how I could get back to the original bytes used. But I guess that’s a win considering I just wanted to prevent brute forcing the password, unless my understanding of this is completely wrong.

if data is not able to be recovered then that’s a hashing algorithm. at that point just use SHA1 or even MD5 because chances are your algorithm has many collisions.

Then should I just perform other operations instead of the modulus?

Are you going for an actual encryption algorithm because if so I’d suggest you look at: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feistel_cipher

but keep the original enciphering methods because I am interested in creating the decipher method.

What do you mean by keep my original methods, but look at the Feistel cipher? If I use that concept for it then it changes my original method.[/quote]

I meant don’t remove it from the thread. Was interested into seeing if it was possible to decipher it.

Read full topic

item.title: Encryption algorithm strength
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:25, topic:431315”][quote author=sp11k3t3ht3rd link=topic=533991.msg3904170#msg3904170 date=1328056412]

Could be unhashed with an linear attack I do believe. You are practically just doing a modulus operation with no other transformation operations? I think the part that would take some thought would be figuring out how many characters there are in the hashed text.

-Amount of represented characters in the string must equal the amount of represented characters in the key.

Is that a rule that you have to follow?

would you like to provide the decryption algorithm please

I don’t know how to decrypt it. Well The mod part is the part that kills me. I don’t know how I could get back to the original bytes used. But I guess that’s a win considering I just wanted to prevent brute forcing the password, unless my understanding of this is completely wrong.

if data is not able to be recovered then that’s a hashing algorithm. at that point just use SHA1 or even MD5 because chances are your algorithm has many collisions.

Then should I just perform other operations instead of the modulus?
[/quote]
modulus is great, it’s just in its purest form you lose information:

m mod n:
5 mod 3 = 2
8 mod 3 = 2

How do you know if 2 came from 5, 8, …, m without retaining how many modulus steps were taken?[/quote]

I know how modulus works, but then doesn’t its use then basically make it a hash function because its “almost” impossible to the back to the original number. Well not almost impossible, but take a lot of time.

[quote=“sinisoul, post:24, topic:431315”][quote author=sp11k3t3ht3rd link=topic=533991.msg3904170#msg3904170 date=1328056412]

Could be unhashed with an linear attack I do believe. You are practically just doing a modulus operation with no other transformation operations? I think the part that would take some thought would be figuring out how many characters there are in the hashed text.

-Amount of represented characters in the string must equal the amount of represented characters in the key.

Is that a rule that you have to follow?

would you like to provide the decryption algorithm please

I don’t know how to decrypt it. Well The mod part is the part that kills me. I don’t know how I could get back to the original bytes used. But I guess that’s a win considering I just wanted to prevent brute forcing the password, unless my understanding of this is completely wrong.

if data is not able to be recovered then that’s a hashing algorithm. at that point just use SHA1 or even MD5 because chances are your algorithm has many collisions.

Then should I just perform other operations instead of the modulus?
[/quote]

Are you going for an actual encryption algorithm because if so I’d suggest you look at: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feistel_cipher

but keep the original enciphering methods because I am interested in creating the decipher method.[/quote]

What do you mean by keep my original methods, but look at the Feistel cipher? If I use that concept for it then it changes my original method.

[quote=“sinisoul, post:20, topic:431315”]Could be unhashed with an linear attack I do believe. You are practically just doing a modulus operation with no other transformation operations? I think the part that would take some thought would be figuring out how many characters there are in the hashed te->3 variations of the string but then that’d create a huge list of possible string. Of course you do have the key == str length rule so that could sort out what is and what is not a valid option.xt.

-Amount of represented characters in the string must equal the amount of represented characters in the key.
-Maximum value from key is 0->text length.
-You cannot have duplicates of values in the key. Therefore the maximum parsed value from the key string (3 characters per value maximum, less than enciphered maximum represented length).

/179/87/31/91/241/151/62/115/211/0/201/41/32/218/0/6/

min - 16

/254/31/28/0/242/169/108/112/102/40/3/

min - 11

/1/7/9/8/7/3/1/9/1/2/4/1/1/5/1/6/2/1/1/5/2/1/1/0/2/0/1/4/1/3/2/2/1/8/0/6/

max - 36? (terribad counting skills)

-Could Remove duplicate entries in key (ascending order)…

/2/5/4/3/1/2/8/0/2/4/2/1/6/9/1/0/8/1/1/2/1/0/2/4/0/3/

max - 26

character range: 11 - 26. (actual characters: 23)

/2/5/4/3/1/2/8/0/2/4/2/1/6/9/1/0/8/1/1/2/1/0/2/4/0/3/

length must equal:

/1/7/9/8/7/3/1/9/1/2/4/1/1/5/1/6/2/1/1/5/2/1/1/0/2/0/1/4/1/3/2/2/1/8/0/6/

kinda lost on where to go from here but my idea now is that you can simply just use the 1->3 variations of the key on the 1->3 variations of the string but then that’d create a huge list of possible string. Of course you do have the key == str length rule so that could sort out what is and what is not a valid option.[/quote]

That’s not exactly how the key works. Add commas to how it’s printed out.

Read full topic

if data is not able to be recovered then that’s a hashing algorithm. at that point just use SHA1 or even MD5 because chances are your algorithm has many collisions.

modulus is great, it’s just in its purest form you lose information:

-Amount of represented characters in the string must equal the amount of represented characters in the key.
-Maximum value from key is 0->text length.
-You cannot have duplicates of values in the key. Therefore the maximum parsed value from the key string (3 characters per value maximum, less than enciphered maximum represented length).

min - 16

/254/31/28/0/242/169/108/112/102/40/3/

min - 11

/1/7/9/8/7/3/1/9/1/2/4/1/1/5/1/6/2/1/1/5/2/1/1/0/2/0/1/4/1/3/2/2/1/8/0/6/

item.title: Encryption algorithm strength
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

RSA (cryptosystem)

RSA (Rivest–Shamir–Adleman) is one of the first public-key cryptosystems and is widely used for secure data transmission. In such a cryptosystem, the encryption key is public and it is different from the decryption key which is kept secret (private). In RSA, this asymmetry is based on the practical difficulty of the factorization of the product of two large prime numbers, the "factoring problem". The acronym RSA is made of the initial letters of the surnames of Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir, and Leonard...

Read full topic
